text: Hello everyone! I was wondering if someone could  give some feedback on my proposal <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xHK7VLnY9VKfboFa2Vn7bgo02WQIagujGhWR0eMZVTg/edit?usp=sharing|here> for working on identifiability problems in Symbolics and ModelingToolkit during Summer of Code? Thank you!

elements.text: Hello everyone! I was wondering if someone could  give some feedback on my proposal
for working on identifiability problems in Symbolics and ModelingToolkit during Summer of Code? Thank you!

text: There doesn't seem to be any prior pull requests in there showing the ability to develop JuliaSymbolics or SciML packages.

elements.text: There doesn't seem to be any prior pull requests in there showing the ability to develop JuliaSymbolics or SciML packages.

text: hey <@U69BL50BF>, could you please elaborate on this requirement?

elements.text: , could you please elaborate on this requirement?

text:
It's not so much a requirement as a proof of ability. Reading your proposal I don't see clear examples that show you can integrate with existing open source software work. Things like, do you know git well enough to rebase and understand concurrent code changes, can you quickly get up to speed with a large library, how do you write unit tests, etc. This aspect is something that is missing. The best thing you could add to reflect this property would be a section where you link to recent pull requests to standard libraries, even if it's just things like JuliaLang/julia or PyCall.jl, that demonstrate this ability. If you don't have that, find something else that makes this point. Otherwise it is an open question, and every open question is an uncertainty. Your current proposal helps me know that you have the mathematical technical ability to write a research software, but GSoC isn't about research software, it's about getting production-quality open source software.

So the proposal is leaving me to guess as to whether you can make that transition, which is a bit risky because I have seen many students, undergrads and PhD, not able to transition from "here's the algorithm write a Julia code" to "here's the algorithm, write an efficient implementation that is parallel, type-generic, not overly verbose, with unit tests that follows the COLPRAC style guides etc. etc." I'll post this to the whole channel because this is something that shows up in a lot of applications (not just yours!), and anything you can do to help the reviewers know you can handle that transition will increase your chances.

(That said, it's not a bad proposal at all, this is the negative point I personally would note in a review of this proposal so hopefully that gives you ample time to address it!)

So the proposal is leaving me to guess as to whether you can make that transition, which is a bit risky because I have seen many students, undergrads and PhD, not able to transition from "here's the algorithm write a Julia code" to "here's the algorithm, write an efficient implementation that is parallel, type-generic, not overly verbose, with unit tests that follows the COLPRAC style guides etc. etc." I'll post this to the whole channel because this is something that shows up in a lot of applications (not just yours!), and anything you can do to help the reviewers know you can handle that transition will increase your chances.

text: Thanks, <@U69BL50BF>, I appreciate the advice and I get the point. I will add some of the examples of my work with git (PRs, packages with unit tests) to showcase what you mentioned though these are not necessarily all Julia packages, unfortunately.
